questions.text: A child presents with anemia, thrombocytopenia. The child also complains of bony pain. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly is seen. Light microscopy reveals crumpled tissue paper appearance. The enzyme defect here is?
questions.solution:
Above is a case of Gaucher’s disease.

Option A: Gluco-Cerebrosidase deficiency can lead to Gaucher disease. It is characterized by enlarged liver and spleen, erosion of long bones, mental retardation in infants

Option B: Sphingomyelinase deficiency can lead to Niemann-Pick disease. It is characterized by enlarged liver and spleen, mental retardation; fatal in early life

Option C: Hexosaminidase A deficiency can lead to Tay-Sachs disease. It is characterised by mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness.

Option D: Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency can lead to Von Gierke disease. It is characterised by glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells; hypoglycemia; lactic acidemia; ketosis; hyperlipemia.

questions.text: The following finding is due to deficiency of
questions.solution:
Above image showing xerophthalmia, which occurs due to vitamin A deficiency.

Option A: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy. Proline and lysine hydroxylases are required for the postsynthetic modification of procollagen to collagen. Both this enzyme requires vitamin C. So signs of vitamin C deficiency include skin changes, fragility of blood capillaries, gum decay, tooth loss and bone fracture, which can be attributed to impaired collagen synthesis(leading to delayed wound healing) and psychological changes that can be attributed to impaired synthesis of catecholamines.

Option B: Vitamin A deficiency is the most important preventable cause of blindness. The earliest sign of deficiency is a loss of sensitivity to green light, followed by impairment to adapt to dim light, then night blindness, an inability to see in the dark.

More prolonged deficiency leads to xerophthalmia: keratinization of the cornea and blindness. 

Option C: Vitamin B deficiency leads to various clinical manifestations, not involving the eye.

Option D: In experimental animals, vitamin E deficiency results in resorption of fetuses and testicular atrophy. Dietary deficiency of vitamin E in human beings is unknown, although patients with severe fat malabsorption, cystic fibrosis and some forms of chronic liver disease suffer deficiency because they are unable to absorb or transport the vitamin, leading to nerve and muscle membrane damage. Premature infants are born with inadequate reserves of the vitamin. The erythrocyte membranes are abnormally fragile as a result of lipid peroxidation, leading to hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activities can be estimated n RBCs to diagnose Vitamin B2 deficiency
questions.solution:
Option A: Thiamin nutritional status can be assessed by erythrocyte transketolase activation.

Option B: Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

Option C: Lower kynureninase activity found in vitamin B6 deficiency.

The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by the activation of erythrocyte transaminases by pyridoxal phosphate added in vitro, expressed as the activation coefficient.

Option D: The role of thiamin diphosphate in pyruvate dehydrogenase means that in deficiency there is impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.

questions.text: DNA packing is done by which of the following proteins
questions.solution:
Option A: Histone is the most abundant chromatin protein, involved in DNA packaging.

Histones are a small family of closely related basic proteins. H1 histones are the ones least tightly bound to chromatin and are, therefore, easily removed with a salt solution, after which chromatin becomes more soluble. The organizational unit of this soluble chromatin is the nucleosome. Nucleosomes contain four major types of histones: H2A, H2B, H3, and H4. The sequence and structures of all four histones, H2A, H2B, H3 and H4, the so-called core histones that form the nucleosome, have been highly conserved between species, although variants of the histones exist and are used for specialized purposes. This extreme conservation implies that the function of histones is identical in all eukaryotes and that the entire molecule is involved quite specifically in carrying out this function. The carboxyl terminal two-thirds of the histone molecules are hydrophobic, while their amino terminal thirds are particularly rich in basic amino acids.

The histones interact with each other in very specific ways. H3 and H4 form a tetramer containing two molecules of each(H3-H4)2, while H2A and H2B form dimers H2A- H2B). Under physiologic conditions, these histone oligomers associate to form the histone octamer of the composition(H3-H4)2-(H2A-H2B)2.

Option B: Glycoprotein is not involved in DNA packing.

Option C: Nucleic acids are DNA & RNA.

Option D: Adenine is a Nitrogen base present in nucleic acid.

questions.text: Series of redox couples arranged in ascending order in the inner mitochondrial membrane makes ETC. There are mainly four complexes. The complex IV inhibitor includes
questions.solution:
Inhibitors of the respiratory chain provided knowledge about the mechanism of action of several poisons & drugs which are fatal at high dose. 

Option A: H2S, carbon monoxide(CO) and cyanide inhibit Complex IV and can therefore totally arrest respiration.

Option B: Carbon monoxide(CO) inhibits Complex IV, not carbon dioxide(CO2).

Option C: The antibiotic oligomycin completely blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by blocking the flow of protons through ATP synthase.

Option D: Ouabain inhibits the Na - K ATPase pump.

Complex I is inhibited by Rotenone, Piericidin A.Barbiturates such as amobarbital also inhibit electron transport via Complex I by blocking the transfer from Fe-S to Q. At sufficiently high dosage, they are fatal.

Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of Complex II.

Antimycin A, dimercaprol & BAL inhibit the respiratory chain at Complex III.

questions.text: Patient from a mediterranean origin went to Africa and developed features of malaria, he is treated with primaquine and later develops hemolytic anemia. This is due to an enzyme deficiency involved in which pathway?
questions.solution:
This is a case of glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. This enzyme is involved in HMP shunt.

Option C: In red blood cells, the pentose phosphate pathway is the sole source of NADPH for the reduction of oxidized glutathione catalyzed by glutathione reductase, a flavoprotein containing flavin adenine dinucleotide(FAD). Reduced glutathione removes H2O2 in a reaction catalyzed by glutathione peroxidase, an enzyme that contains the selenium analog of cysteine at the active site. The reaction is important since accumulation of H2O2 may decrease the life span of the erythrocyte by causing oxidative damage to the cell membrane, leading to hemolysis.

In some populations, glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is common enough for it to be regarded as a genetic polymorphism. The distribution of mutant genes parallels that of malaria, suggesting that being heterozygous confers resistance against malaria. The defect is manifested as red cell hemolysis(hemolytic anemia) when susceptible individuals are subjected to oxidative stress from infection, drugs such as the antimalarial primaquine and sulfonamides or when they have eaten fava beans (Vicia faba-hence the name of the disease, favism).

Option A: Glycolysis involved in breakdown of glucose into pyruvate or lactate, to produce energy.

Option B: Gluconeogenesis produces glucose from lactate, glycerol, amino acid(alanine) & propionic acid. It occurs in fasting conditions, to provide glucose and maintain glucose level.

Option D: Rapaport pathway occurs in mature RBC involving formation of 2,3 - diphosphoglycerate, which regulate oxygen release from Hb.

questions.text: Single mutation in a nucleotide base pair changing it from protein coding to terminating codon is known as?
questions.solution:
Option A: A missense effect will occur when a different amino acid is incorporated at the corresponding site in the protein molecule. This mistaken amino acid-or missense, depending on its location in the specific protein-might be acceptable, partially acceptable or unacceptable to the function of that protein molecule.

Option B: A nonsense codon may appear that would then result in the premature termination of translation and the production of only a fragment of the intended protein molecule. The probability is high that a prematurely terminated protein molecule or peptide fragment will not function in its normal role.

Option C: A normal codon turns into a stop codon(UAA, UAG, UGA), so protein synthesis terminates.

Option D: There may be no detectable effect because of the degeneracy of the code; such mutations are often referred to as silent mutations. This would be most likely if the changed base in the Mrna molecule were to be at the third nucleotide of a codon. Because of wobble, the translation of a codon is least sensitive to a change at the third position.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in transport of fatty acids across the inner mitochondrial membrane in a cardiac muscle?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acyl carrier protein(ACP) has a similar function to that of CoA in the β-oxidation pathway. It contains the vitamin pantothenic acid in the form of 4′-phosphopantetheine. During fatty acid synthesis, initially a priming molecule of acetyl-CoA combines with a cysteine -SH group, while malonyl-CoA combines with the adjacent -SH on the 4′-phosphopantetheine of ACP of the other monomer.

Option B: Long-chain fatty acids cross the inner mitochondrial membrane as carnitine derivatives. Carnitine(β-hydroxy-γ-trimethylammonium butyrate), is widely distributed and is particularly abundant in muscle. Long-chain acyl-CoA(or FFA) cannot penetrate the inner membrane of mitochondria. In the presence of carnitine, however, carnitine palmitoyltransferase-I, located in the outer mitochondrial membrane, transfers the long-chain acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming acylcarnitine and releasing CoA. Acylcarnitine is able to penetrate the inner membrane and gain access to the β-oxidation system of enzymes via the inner membrane exchange transporter carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase. The transporter binds acylcarnitine and transports it across the membrane in exchange for carnitine. The acyl group is then transferred to CoA so that acyl-CoA is reformed and carnitine is liberated. This reaction is catalyzed by carnitine palmitoyltransferase-II, which is located on the inside of the inner membrane.

Option C: Lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase(LCAT) enzyme is found in plasma, catalyzes the transfer of a fatty acid residue from the 2 position of lecithin to cholesterol to form cholesteryl ester and lysolecithin and is considered to be responsible for much of the cholesteryl ester in plasma lipoproteins.

Lecithin: cholesterol acyltransferase(LCAT) activity is associated with HDL containing apo A-I. As cholesterol in HDL becomes esterified, it creates a concentration gradient and draws in cholesterol from tissues and from other lipoproteins, thus enabling HDL to function in reverse cholesterol transport.

Option D: Albumin transport various ligands, including bilirubin, free fatty acids, ions [Ca2+], metals[eg, Cu2+, Zn2+], metheme, steroids, other hormones and a variety of drugs.

questions.text: A 16 year old boy presented with pain in the muscles during exercise. He also has symptoms of discoloured urine. Which enzyme defect can cause this
questions.solution:
Option A: Myophosphorylase deficiency(McArdle syndrome) leads to poor exercise tolerance; muscle glycogen abnormally high(2.5 -- 4%); blood lactate very low after exercise.

Discolored urine may be due to excretion of myoglobin in urine.

Option B: Hexokinase(enzyme involved in glycolysis) deficiency may lead to hemolytic anemia, fatigue.

Option C: Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency can lead to Von Gierke disease, which is characterized by glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells; hypoglycemia; lactic acidemia; ketosis; hyperlipidemia.

Option D: Liver glycogen phosphorylase deficiency can lead to Hers disease, which is characterized by hepatomegaly; accumulation of glycogen in liver; mild hypoglycemia; generally good prognosis

questions.text: Case history of paint factory worker working since 20 years, came with complaints of joint pain, insomnia, fatigue, constipation and headache. He is found to have anemia. Which enzyme is affected?
questions.solution:
The enzyme affected in lead poisoning that is relevant to the symptoms described is:

(d) Ferrochelatase

Explanation:

  • Lead interferes with several enzymes involved in heme synthesis. One key enzyme affected is ferrochelatase.
  • Ferrochelatase is responsible for the final step in heme synthesis, where iron (Fe^2+) is inserted into protoporphyrin IX to form heme.
  • Inhibition of ferrochelatase by lead results in decreased heme production. This can lead to anemia due to decreased hemoglobin synthesis, which manifests as fatigue and possibly other symptoms such as joint pain, headache, and insomnia.
  • Lead toxicity can also cause gastrointestinal symptoms like constipation.

Therefore, among the options provided, (d) Ferrochelatase is the enzyme affected in this case of lead poisoning.

questions.text: A woman on anti-depressants presents with bleeding. She gives history of bulky stools, which stick to the pan. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies can cause bleeding in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of clotting factors in the liver, specifically factors II, VII, IX, and X.
  • Malabsorption of fats can lead to deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins like Vitamin K.
  • Vitamin K deficiency can result in impaired blood clotting, leading to easy bruising and bleeding tendencies.
  • The symptoms of bulky stools that stick to the pan suggest fat malabsorption, which can lead to deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins including Vitamin K.

Therefore, in a woman presenting with bleeding and symptoms suggestive of malabsorption (bulky stools), Vitamin K deficiency (option d) is the most likely cause of the bleeding due to impaired clotting factor synthesis.

choices.text: With aging. There is shortening of telomeres
With aging. There is an increase in the length of telomeres
Telomeres are replenished in somatic cells

questions.solution:
• Telomeres are repetitive sequences of nucleotides located at the ends of chromosomes, consisting of TTAGGG repeats in humans.
  • telomeres protect the ends of chromosomes from degradation and fusion with neighboring chromosomes.
  • During cellular replication, telomeres shorten due to the end replication problem, where DNA polymerase cannot fully replicate the 3' end of linear DNA.
  • Telomere shortening is considered a marker of cellular aging and is associated with the aging process.
  • In somatic cells, telomeres are not replenished; they gradually shorten with each cell division. Telomeres do not contain coding sequences; their primary function is to protect the integrity of chromosomes.

Therefore, the correct statement regarding telomeres is (a) With aging, there is shortening of telomeres.

questions.text: A known patient of Tuberculosis, who is on INH for six months, present with tingling sensation and paraesthesia. Deficiency of which of the following vitamins is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
• Isoniazid (INH), which is commonly used to treat tuberculosis, can lead to peripheral neuropathy due to its effect on pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) metabolism.
  • INH can inhibit pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of Vitamin B6, which is essential for nerve function.
  • Deficiency of Vitamin B6 can result in symptoms such as tingling sensation, paraesthesia (abnormal sensations), and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A patient come to hospital with diarrhea, complaining of Rice water stools, intoxication is due to involvement of which of the following:
questions.solution:
• The description of "rice water stools" is characteristic of cholera, which is caused by Vibrio cholerae.
  • Cholera toxin binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of intestinal cells.
  • Activation of the GM1 ganglioside receptor leads to the secretion of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, causing the characteristic watery diarrhea (rice water stools).

questions.text:
Identify the acid base disorder in a patient with the following values:
pH = 7.2
pO2 = 90mm of Hg
pCO2 = 80mm of Hg
[HCO3] = 35 mEq /L
questions.solution:
• In respiratory acidosis, the pH is decreased (<7.35) and the pCO2 is increased (>45 mmHg).
  • In this case, the pH is low (7.2) and the pCO2 is elevated (80 mmHg), indicating respiratory acidosis.
  • The elevated pCO2 suggests that there is inadequate ventilation leading to retention of carbon dioxide and subsequent acidosis.
